articles.author: David Shepardson
articles.description: The U.S. Federal Aviation Administration said on Wednesday night that a PSA Airlines regional jet collided midair with a Sikorsky H-60 helicopter while on approach to Reagan Washington National Airport.
articles.title: Regional jet collides with helicopter near Washington's Reagan Airport

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: Militants from Hamas and allied groups Islamic Jihad and Popular Resistance Committees arrived at a site in Khan Younis in Gaza ahead of the handover of Israeli hostages on Thursday Hamas sources and witnesses said, as part of a ceasefire deal.
articles.title: Palestinian militants arrive at Gaza site before hostage handover, militant sources and witnesses say

articles.author: Jonathan Landay, Aram Roston
articles.description: A small U.S. security firm is hiring nearly 100 U.S. special forces veterans to help run a checkpoint in Gaza during the Israel-Hamas truce, introducing armed American contractors into the heart of one of the world's most violent conflict zones.
articles.title: Exclusive: Inside a US security firm's risky Gaza mission

articles.author: Olena Harmash
articles.description: Some 150 Ukrainian teenagers from northeastern areas near the frontlines of the war with Russia had already packed their bags to travel west for an educational retreat far from the shelling and fighting. Their plans were abruptly cancelled.
articles.title: Ukraine aid groups cut services, scramble for cash after US funding shock

articles.author: Yassin Kombi, Sonia Rolley
articles.description: Rwandan President Paul Kagame blasted criticism of his country's role in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo where rebels his government backs have seized its largest city, saying Kigali is prepared for "confrontation" if necessary.
articles.title: Rwanda's Kagame defiant on criticism of east Congo offensive; rebels push south

articles.author: Saurabh Sharma, Shivam Patel
articles.description: Police said 30 people were killed in the crush at the world's biggest gathering of humanity, but sources told Reuters the death toll was nearly 40.
articles.title: India orders probe into Kumbh festival stampede that killed dozens

articles.author: Gabriel Stargardter
articles.description: French far-right leader Marine Le Pen on Thursday said those behind death threats against a judge and prosecutors trying her in a graft trial should be punished, in her first comments on a police investigation into the abuse.
articles.title: France's Le Pen condemns death threats against those trying her

articles.author: Daniel Wiessner
articles.description: The Trump administration has unveiled a novel plan offering financial incentives to 2 million civilian full-time federal workers to quit their jobs as part of a planned cull of the government workforce. But the program is likely to run into a number of complications, including funding issues, and it could also face legal challenges.
articles.title: Explainer: Can Trump pay US government employees to quit their jobs?

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: A British man captured fighting on the Ukrainian side in Russia's Kursk region will face terrorism and mercenary charges that could see him jailed for years, Russian state investigators said on Thursday.
articles.title: Russia accuses British man caught fighting for Ukraine of terrorism

articles.author: Jacob Gronholt-Pedersen, Gwladys Fouche
articles.description: In 2023, Mads Petersen, owner of Greenland-based startup Arctic Unmanned, sat in a car to keep warm while he tested a small drone at minus 43 degrees Celsius (minus 45 degrees Fahrenheit).
articles.title: ‘We’re all having to catch up’: NATO scrambles for drones that can survive the Arctic
